text:
- Hi, I'm Tamar Bercovici,
VP Engineering at Box.

- I'm Ben Kus, Chief
Technology Officer at Box.

All right, three words to
describe Box and AWS partnership.

- Well, first off, I'd start
by saying best-of-breed.
This is something
that's very fundamental to the philosophy,
both of Box and how we've been building

our platform and our
product as well as AWS,

and that ability to
integrate and to configure
and to have that flexibility.
And so both our ability to integrate

with our own services
and then also expand that

into the broader ecosystem,
I think has been-
- And Box is best of breed, right?

- Of course.
- And so is AWS.

- Of course.
- And Bedrock

and all their models, just-
- Of course.

Of course.
- Check, check, check. Okay.

- Yes.
- That's one.
- Two, trust.
A core tenet of what we want to build

into our platform is
to be the trusted place
for enterprises to put their best,
most important, most high value content.

And so security and sort of
the various kind of controls

that go with that are
very key to our product,

and an important element
within that is to ensure

that we're working with
trusted, the best brands,

the best trusted vendors
that we can partner with,
and AWS is definitely one of those.
- And before you throw any names,
insert a quick customer reference just to.

So I was talking to
somebody yesterday here,
and we were talking about our AI,

and they were like,
"Okay, so I trust you Box,

but I don't know if I
trust like the AI you use."
And we're like, "Well, we use AWS."
I'm like, "Okay, like, good."
Like, I don't think I've ever met anybody
who doesn't trust AWS.
- Exactly, exactly.
- So that's two.
- Innovation.
We're here talking about Gen AI.
That's definitely innovative.

It's been so exciting to
see all the new models
coming out seemingly every Tuesday.

And so it's been a fantastic
opportunity for us to be able

to leverage the innovative
technology coming from AWS

into innovative product
experiences for our customers.
- And if you make those into a acronym,
would you call it BIT to reorganize them
or would you do TIB?
We'll move on.

- How does Box ensure
data privacy and security
when using AWS foundation models?

- So for us, this goes back
to the, I think the key thing

is that we're an
enterprise-grade company, right?
We have 115,000 enterprise customers
and across different industries,

each of them has these
like really important data
that they trust Box to.

And so when you're using
AI on this kind of content,

or if you're enabling
it for customers to use,
if they can't trust the idea

that the data is safe and
secure, then they won't use it.

Like straight up won't
even consider using it.
And so for us, we have to apply

our enterprise-grade principles
on the way that we do AI.
And one of the first,

I mean, we've published
these AI principles,
but one of the key things

is that we are not going to
train on customer's data.
Customer's data is customer's data.
And this is very critical to them.

And, and then they always ask
the question which is like,

well, how can I, like, I
can trust you for that,

but how do I trust the
people that you're using?
And this goes back to the idea
of Amazon is quite trustworthy.
So when we hook up the foundation models,
we do it according to the, you know, ways

that we would ensure
the models are isolated,
ensuring that the data isn't retained
for longer than it needs to be.
If you're going to log the transactions,
you don't log the data associated with it.

But then also there's
this fundamental idea
of no training on your data

because that would be
potentially turn into
a data leakage event.
And customer's data is customer's data,

so and that's what Amazon
believes, that's what we believe.
And that's really critical.
You set the whole thing up
so that you can get the benefits of AI

without having the
downsides of AI gone wrong.

- Okay, Ben, what
modifications were required
in Box's existing infrastructure
to support Amazon Bedrock integration?
So we had built an AI platform
whose job was to kind of go through
and be able to do the retrieval
augmented generation on the content,
kind of retrieve the snippets,
be able to do the embeddings and all that.

And then the key was that
once you kind of gather
the most relevant data,

you need to provide it to
the AI with the right prompts
to be able to then have it respond.
And so, you know, and at some point,
if you have many different models,

Because like there's a
lot of them out there,

you would have to then,
you know, redo that work
for all of the different models.

And one of the really
cool things about Bedrock
was that it kind of gives you all of that
in one sort of simple connection.
And it's basically a configuration option

of which model is the one
you want to send it to.
And that is just kind of super amazing.

So if there's like a brand new
like, oh, something came out,

it's the newest greatest
model that's ever existed,

which kind of happens
every couple of weeks now,
then you're just like,

"Oh, change the configuration
option and now try."

And, there's no real,
like, hard development work

or even like, not hard,
but cumbersome work,
and it's just kind of all connected.

And I think that's a really
nice feature of Bedrock.

- And it's been a very,
very smooth process.

What are you most excited
about, Ben, coming forward?

- Well, so one of the things
that I sort of appreciate
that we're in the middle of right now
is that you can't go very long
without having a new AI model come out

that's like the best
AI model in the world.

It's like if we had looked
like three years ago,
like this would've been considered one of

the ultimate like technology
achievements in the world.
And then for me, the idea of using these
not just in sort of an AI system approach,

but more of an agentic AI
agentic workflows approach.
For us, we're all about content,
so being able to apply AI
in your content and agentic workflows,

these are kind of the
really new cool things
that we're very excited about.
Not only the new models,

but also just working with
AWS on these kinds of things.

- Yeah, I think the
whole direction of agents

is going to be the next wave
of technological innovation

that we're going to see from
the base models coming in
with a lot more reasoning and ability

to kind of take time and
do more complex tasks,
but then also almost like a new way
in which we integrate across our systems

with shifting from a kind
of a strict API interface

to more a collaboration
model between AI agents.

That's pretty exciting.
- I think it's going to sound
weird in the future when we say,

well, like the Box AI agent
was talking to like Amazon Q,
and then they like talk to...

Like, you, like, we'll
like, refer to these

as little like, entities that
go out and do things for you.

- And then they somehow all
helped us do better, right?
- Yeah, absolutely.
